review_title: Don't Believe the Negative Reviews!  Best Company in Tulsa!
pros: I've worked for this company a long time, this is by far the most rewarding experience of my life.  The company is VERY honest and take their Core Values seriously.  This Company does not tolerate dishonesty, continued poor work ethics or violations of no tolerance policies such as sexual harassment or positive drug tests.  Employees who have been terminated, are no longer with the company for a VERY good reason and those are the few disgruntled employees who make negative comments.  The work environment is one that encourages professional growth and development.  Employees who do well are rewarded and promotions are frequent in this Company.  The benefits are AMAZING, where else can you get a monthly Spa service?  Not to mention great insurance, paid vacations, holidays and personal time.  They even offer a full service Gym to promote health and wellness.  I'm so grateful to have the opportunity to work with amazing people such as the Owner and CEO Teresa Knox, who started this company when she was a dental assistant.  Going to a career college changed her life and in turn she has changed thousands of lives in the almost twenty years the school has been around. Dr. Kirk is the president of the Company and a true servant leader.  The Company cares about each and every student, it's not about the money and never has been in the years I've worked here.  I plan to retire with this extraordinary Company!
cons: I cannot think of any cons presently in the Company.  If you do not fit into the culture and do not care about helping others then this is not the company for you.

pros: Formed many wonderful friendships and enjoyed great perks such as free massage and generous discounts on goods and services.  Nice facilities.
cons:
It may seem excessive to describe this organization as cult like, but I can't say how many times that very word crossed my mind while working there.  I snicker as I read a review written by a current employee raving about the low turnover rate, putting God first and the positive, life changing impact the school has on students.  I remember being regaled with the same tellings during an employment interview at Community Care College and later found absolutely no validity whatsoever in these canned talking points.

I had the misfortune of being seated within earshot of a department that sued dropouts.  Listening as former students would literally beg, cry and plead that a lawsuit garnishing their already meager wages for the inability to make payments be  dropped.  I was horrified by some of the ghastly responses such as "it's not my problem" and "you should have thought about this before you enrolled", or "well, that's just too bad."  Locks were placed on certain departments doors shortly after this practice began.  Hearing these sorts of conversations  marked the lowest point of my employment time at CCC and necessitated the employment of some heavy duty mental gymnastics before reporting to work each day.

In the open air, management required that the financial aid department not "package" new enrollees who brought with them large amounts of existing student loan debt along with a history of multiple drops from other schools nobly suggesting that an almost inevitable repeat would only deepen the existing hole of a potential student.  I can't  count the number of those that fit this very scenario who were enrolled and saddled with even more loan debt only to drop  a short time later.  Looking back, I feel shame that I played a role in robbing others of any hope of financial freedom, the very thing that brought them to the doors of CCC. 

There were bloodbaths of layoffs and firings.  I recall the insult and anguish of a good number close friends as they were forced to fight for unemployment benefits after it was said that their dismissal was due to spending too much time on the internet, which, in every case was later disproven.  

The glowing reviews on this site are unsurprising, as I recall that on at least two occasions I (as well as many others) was required to publicly express positive statements about the school.  One in the form of a written statement regarding what a great company CCC was to work for and the other a video recording of what a great benefit the school was to it's students.  I reluctantly did as I was told, but didn't dare tout the "God first" tenant, as by doing so  marking myself a charlatan. 

Job placement  is a joke.  Graduates were regularly placed in jobs that had very little connection to their respective field of study.  

This new talk of being non-profit is a smoke screen.  There are 101 ways to be classified as such and still direct dollars dirctly into the pockets of owners and shareholders.  

While my salary was decent, I would never  work for this company again.  It made me feel dirty and shameful.  I regret having stayed as long as I did, especially after discovering it's nasty inner workings.
